ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Growth and optical characterization of diamond-shaped zinc oxide nanostructures deposited by pulsed laser ablation

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
We report on the growth of zinc oxide diamond-shaped nanostructured thin films by pulsed laser deposition technique on silicon substrate at different substrate temperatures (room temperature to 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C) and at fixed background pressure of oxygen using Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 532 nm. The influence of substrate temperature on the grain size, surface morphology and optical properties is characterized by x-ray diffraction, field-emission scanning electron microscope, photoluminescence and Raman spectroscopy. x-ray diffraction results show that the grain size increases with increasing substrate temperature during the growth of ZnO thin films due to improved crystallinity but at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C the crystallinity degrades. It is attributed to the formation of diamond-shaped ZnO nanostructures as supported by the field emission scanning electron microscope images. Consequently, increase in photoluminescence and Raman intensities is also attributed to the formation of diamond-shaped structures. The growth of diamond-shaped structure is discussed in the light of growth of various planes in the hexagonal structure of ZnO.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Zinc oxide (ZnO) is one of the wide band-gap semiconductors, 3.37 eV at room temperature (RT) [1], suitable for ultra-violet (UV), blue light emitting diodes and UV lasers [2]. It has large exciton binding energy (
$$\sim $$
∼
60 meV) compared to gallium nitride (
$$\sim $$
∼
25 meV) [3] that ensures efficient excitonic emission at RT. ZnO-based nanostructured materials have gained importance in science and technology resulting in interesting properties due to surface and quantum confinement effects. To facilitate these properties ZnO nanostructures have been grown into various shapes viz., pyramid, prisms, dots, nanowires, nanorods etc. using various deposition techniques like hydrothermal process [4, 5], aqueous chemical growth [6], pulsed laser deposition (PLD) [7–9], etc. PLD is one of the versatile techniques that have been used effectively for the growth of ZnO thin film, since it allows for controlled growth of various materials while preserving the stoichiometry of the source material upon transport from target to substrate and hence there is no need of using any catalyst [10]. ZnO thin films have been grown on different substrates such as sapphire, silicon (Si), and quartz glass [11–13] at different substrate temperatures and at ambient pressures of gases like oxygen, argon, and nitrogen [12, 14, 15].

The morphology of different structures has been attributed to the extent to which the raw material has been used especially when a catalyst is involved in the growth process [16]. The photoluminescence studies on these different structures have revealed the dominance of the exciton emission band near 390 nm for pyramid-like ZnO nanostructures along with some very weak deep level defect related emission band at 500–650 nm [17, 18]. In the present work, however, we report on the growth of diamond-shaped ZnO nanostructures (refers to the appearance of these structures and not to be confused with the diamond-structure as such which is cubic) using PLD without the use of any catalyst at various substrate temperatures on Si substrate. These structures are different from the pyramid-like morphology. In the growth process, we observed the formation of diamond-shaped structures at the substrate temperature of 150 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C with such structures being more prominent at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C and are reported for the first time to the best of our knowledge using PLD technique. The effect of deposition time on the growth of diamond-shaped structures at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate is also discussed to understand the growth mechanism. The films deposited at various substrate temperatures have been characterized using x-ray diffraction (XRD), field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM), photoluminescence (PL) and Raman spectroscopy (RS) and our studies very well augment these characterization techniques. The enhancement in the PL intensity reported in the present work is a good indication of use of such structures in lasing.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
ZnO targets were prepared using polyvenyl alcohol as the binder. The targets were pressed at 3 ton and sintered at 1,000
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C for 5 h. The schematic diagram of PLD set-up used for the growth of ZnO nanostructures is shown in Fig. 1. The Q-switched Nd:YAG laser (Quanta laser, HYL-101,
$$\lambda $$
λ
= 532 nm, pulse width 10 ns) at the repetition rate of 10 Hz was focused on the surface of ZnO target. The laser fluence was 12 J/cm
$$^{2}$$
2
. The target was rotated continuously so that the laser pulse falls on its fresh surface. The ZnO thin films were deposited on Silicon substrate in the oxygen (O
$$_{2})$$
2
)
ambient maintained at 0.1 mbar in the vacuum chamber. The base pressure in the vacuum chamber was 10
$$^{-5}$$
- 5
mbar. The target-substrate distance was fixed at 4 cm. The deposition time was 20 min. The nanostructured thin films on Si substrate were deposited at different substrate temperatures—room temperature (RT, 23
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C), 150, 300, 450 and 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, respectively. After fixing all the parameters like laser fluence, O
$$_{2}$$
2
pressure, laser wavelength and the substrate temperature at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, films were then deposited for 10, 20, 40 and 60 min time to look at the formation of diamond-shaped structures.
Fig. 1
Schematic diagram of PLD set-up for the growth of ZnO thin films

Section2.Heading: X-ray diffraction analysis

CaptionContent.SimplePara:
XRD spectra of (a) bulk ZnO, (b)–(f) thin films deposited on Si substrate at 0.1 mbar O
$$_{2}$$
2
pressure and at substrate temperature of RT, 150, 300, 450, and 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C

Section2.Para:
The XRD (Bruker Advance D8 with Cuk
$$\alpha $$
α
radiation) of ZnO thin films was done using a CuK
$$\alpha $$
α
1 source at a wavelength of 1.54 A
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
. Figure 2a shows the XRD spectra of the sintered ZnO pellet which shows all the planes corresponding to ZnO. Figure 2b–f shows the XRD spectra of the films deposited at substrate temperatures ranging from RT to 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C and have been identified with the available literature [19, 20]. Figure 2b, at RT, shows a broad and very less intense XRD peak at 56.6
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
corresponding to (110) plane indicating that the film is almost amorphous as no preferred orientation is observed [21]. This peak is not observed at other temperatures in the present study.

When the substrate temperature is increased beyond RT, XRD peak at 34.4
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
corresponding to (002) plane (JCPDS Number–ICSD#: 067849) appeared at 150, 300 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C respectively, as shown in Fig. 2c–e. Since this is the only plane observed at 150, 300 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperatures, the films are highly oriented and single crystal in nature. At 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature, (103) plane at 62.8
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
along with (002) plane is observed in the thin films as shown in Fig. 2f. The single crystal nature of the thin films beyond RT is due to the surface mobility of the impinging atoms sufficient enough to allow the atoms to occupy proper ZnO lattice sites. However, this will certainly not be true at sufficiently high temperatures, since the mobility will then be high enough to knock-out the atoms from preferred lattice sites and the film will again tend to show polycrystalline nature. This indeed is observed for the thin films deposited at substrate temperature of 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, where along with the peak corresponding to (002) plane, a less intense peak at corresponding to (103) plane is also observed [20].

We also observed that the peak intensity of (002) plane increased gradually from 150 to 300
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, decreased at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C and increased again at 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C (Fig. 2c–f). The intensity of ZnO (002) peak in XRD pattern mainly depends on the number of grains with the
$$c$$
c
-axis orientation, high crystallinity, and regular arrangement of nanoparticles in the thin film [21]. The observed intensity behavior can be attributed to an increase in the number of grains and crystallinity with
$$c$$
c
-axis orientation except at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature. At this temperature, the intensity of the peak corresponding to (002) plane decreased drastically indicating that the nanostructures are not highly oriented, have poor crystallinity and irregular arrangement of nanoparticles. The full-width-half-maximum (FWHM) is inversely proportional to the film crystallinity [12]. The FWHM of the peak corresponding to (002) plane has a lower value for the films grown at 300 and 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, and a higher value at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, as shown in Fig. 3. We attribute poor orientation and crystallinity, and irregular arrangement to the formation of diamond-shaped nanostructures as is also evident from the FE-SEM images of ZnO thin film discussed in the next section.
Fig. 3
Plot of FWHM of XRD diffraction peak corresponding to (002) plane with the substrate temperature

Section2.Heading: Surface morphology
Section2.Para:
Figure 4a–e shows the FE-SEM (Sigma, Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany) images of the ZnO nanostructures grown at RT, 150, 300, 450, 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, respectively, at O
$$_{2 }$$
2
pressure of 0.1 mbar. Diamond-shaped structures are prominently observed at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature as shown in Fig. 4d, however, thin film at 150
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C also showed a few such structures. The formation of diamond-shaped structure of ZnO has been reported in the literature grown by oxidation–sublimation process in presence of carbon catalysis [16] and thermolysis of Zn-Oleate complex [17].
Fig. 4
FE-SEM images (at 100K
$$\times $$
×
magnification) of ZnO thin films deposited on Si substrate at 0.1 mbar O
$$_{2}$$
2
pressure and at substrate temperature of (a) RT, (b) 150
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, (c) 300
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, (d) 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, and (e) 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C

The formation of various kinds of ZnO structures is reported in the literature [18, 22, 23] including pyramid-like structures. We believe that the formation of diamond-shaped ZnO also follows the mechanism responsible for the growth of pyramid-like structures and more conducive at the reported temperatures (150 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C) and predominantly at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C. Though the reason for the growth of diamond-shaped structures at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature is not very clear, we have attempted to discuss the formation of diamond-shaped structures in the view of growth rates of several faces of ZnO [22]. Figure 5a–e shows the variation of number of grains with grain size for the films at various substrate temperatures. The grain size is larger for the substrate temperatures 150 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C. At substrate temperature of 300 and 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, the grain size decreases.
Fig. 5
Particle size distribution in ZnO thin films deposited on Si substrate at 0.1 mbar O
$$_2$$
2
pressure and at substrate temperature of (a) RT, (b) 150
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, (c) 300
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, (d) 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, and (e) 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C

We attempted to look at the growth of diamond-shaped structures at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C by depositing them for 10, 20, 40 and 60 min, respectively. The FE-SEM images of the nanostructures are shown in Fig. 6a–d. Figure 6a1 is the enlarged view of a section of Fig. 6a. For 10 min deposition, a few diamond-shaped particles along with background particles are observed. In addition to these structures, several hexagonal structures are clearly observed whereas they are not observed at other deposition temperatures. For 20 min deposition, diamond-shaped structures along with various shaped nanoparticles in the background are observed, whereas for the sample with 40 min deposition, the various shaped nanoparticle with a few diamond-shaped structures are observed. The size of the diamond-shaped structures is much larger than the background particles for the sample with 20 min deposition time as well as for 10 min unlike the sample with 40 min (Fig. 6c) deposition time where the size of the nanoparticles is larger than the size of the diamond-shaped structures. However, for 60 min time (Fig. 6d), both the nanobelts and nanowires are observed. The particle size distribution of the nanostructures grown for 10, 20 and 40 min is given in Fig. 7a–c.
Fig. 6
FE-SEM images of ZnO nanostructures deposited on Si substrate at 0.1 mbar O
$$_2$$
2
pressure and at deposition time of (a) 10 min, (b) 20 min (c) 40 min and (d) 60 min
Fig. 7
Particle size distribution in ZnO thin films deposited on Si substrate at 0.1 mbar O
$$_2$$
2
pressure and at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature and deposition time of (a) 10 min (b) 20 min and (c) 40 min

Let us look at the growth mechanism of diamond-shaped nanoparticles in the light of the FE-SEM images of the nanostructures grown for 10, 20 and 40 min. As the substrate temperature remains fixed for the deposition of all nanostructures, the substrate temperature gives the same amount of surface mobility to the deposited atoms to get the lowest thermodynamically favored lattice positions and therefore the deposition time plays an important role for the growth of various shaped nanostructures. For 10 min, very few diamond-shaped structures are observed, whereas many clear hexagonal structures (in a rectangular white colour box) of size around (40–50 nm) are observed in the background. As we increase the deposition time to 20 min more diamond-shaped structures are observed with slightly increased size. The size of the background particles remains the same and the hexagonal structures are not visible for 20 min deposition.

It is reported that the growth of the crystals is determined by the internal structure of that material [24]. As ZnO has the hexagonal structure, it can be grown as a hexagon but the diamond-shaped structure can be explained in terms of the different growth rates of the hexagonal planes. Various planes that may contribute to the growth habit of ZnO includes
$$[0001]$$
[ 0001 ]
,
$$[000\bar{1}]$$
[ 000
1
¯
]
,
$$\{01\bar{1}1\}$$
{ 01
1
¯
1 }
,
$$\{01\bar{1}0\}$$
{ 01
1
¯
0 }
, and
$$\{01\bar{1}\bar{1}\}$$
{ 01
1
¯
1
¯
}
, respectively [24]. The prismatic shape of ZnO is already reported for the hydrothermal growth in different literatures [22, 24]. Figure 8 shows these directions as observed in the growth of diamond-shaped structures in the present work. We observe that the growth along [0001] is maximum and hence the XRD shows a drastic dip in the (002) direction. The absence of the plane along
$$\{01\bar{1}0\}$$
{ 01
1
¯
0 }
gives rise to the diamond-shaped structure. The growth velocities seem to follow the trend
$$V_{[0001]} > V_{\{01\bar{1}1\}} > V_{\{01\bar{1}\bar{1}\}} > V_{[000\bar{1}]}$$
V
[ 0001 ]
>
V

¯

¯

V
[ 000
1
¯
]
(see Fig. 8). In our case, the ratio of the length of the longer region to that of the shorter region of the diamond-shaped structure is found to be around 3:1 elucidating the formation of diamond-shaped structure. For the nanostructures grown for 10 min the FE-SEM images show several hexagonal structures (size
$$\sim $$
∼
50–60 nm) along with very few diamond-shaped structures (small sized). Different sizes of the diamond-shaped structures can be attributed to different nucleation sites.
Fig. 8
Formation of diamond-shaped structures

For 40 min deposition time, very few diamond-shaped structures of same size are observed while the size of the background particles increased drastically. As the size of the background particles is more than the diamond-shaped particles, very few diamond-shaped structures are observed.

Section2.Heading: Photoluminescence
Section2.Para:
PL (ThermoSpectronic, AB2, monochromator xenon flash lamp) studies were carried out using a Xenon flash lamp operating at 325 nm as the excitation source. Figure 9a shows the PL spectrum of a bulk ZnO. It is observed that the free excitonic peak occurs at around 400 nm (UV peak) and a blue-green peak at 466 nm [25]. The UV peak is dominant near band edge emission peak. Figure 9b shows the PL spectrum of ZnO thin films at O
$$_{2}$$
2
pressure 0.1 mbar and at different substrate temperatures (RT, 150, 300, 450 and 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C). It has been reported that the UV emission comes from ZnO films with low crystal defects or from (002) oriented films [13]. At RT, the crystallinity is poor. As we increase the temperature the crystallinity improves and at 150 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C, PL intensity increases. But from XRD results, it is clear that the films grown at these temperatures have poor crystalline quality and do not have intense (002) peak. The only possible reason for such a high intense peak is the growth of particulates distributed randomly and possibly with shapes different from the ones compared to that grown at other substrate temperatures. As discussed in the previous section, we observed diamond-shaped structure on the grown films (in agreement with the FE-SEM images shown in Fig. 4b, d) and multiple reflections from the facets of such structure will result in an enhancement in the PL intensity. PL intensity is more at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C as compared to 150
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C since the number of diamond-shaped structures are more at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C. The blue-green peak at 467 nm is due to the defect levels such as oxygen vacancies or the interstitial Zn [24]. Low intense blue peaks are observed in all the films along with the bulk Zn. Slightly intense blue peaks are observed at 150
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C and at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C and are attributed to the interstitial Zn defect. Weaker deep level emissions at around 600 nm are also observed in the films. These deep level emissions are due to the structural defects. But, negligibly weak deep level emission compared to strong UV emission demonstrates that the grown films has low structural defect [12, 26]. Figure 10 is the plot of the ratio of the intensity of UV to Visible (blue-green) region with the substrate temperature. This ratio is maximum for the structures grown at 300 and 600
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C indicating the low structural defects in the nanostructures. This ratio is lowest at RT. However, this ratio is more at 150
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C than at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C indicating more structural defects at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C. This is also consistent with the XRD results.
Fig. 9
PL spectrum of (a) bulk ZnO and (b) ZnO thin film deposited on Si substrate at 0.1 mbar O
$$_{2}$$
2
pressure and at various substrate temperatures
Fig. 10
Plot of intensity ratio of UV to Visible (blue-green region) PL spectra with substrate temperature

Figure 11 shows the PL spectra of the nanostructures deposited at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C for 10, 20, 40 and 60 min. The near band edge emission at around 395 nm, defect related emissions at 467 and 595 nm are clear from the PL spectra of all the nanostructures. Strong UV emission is observed for all the nanostructures. This is due to free exciton–exciton recombination or near band edge transition of wide band gap ZnO [27]. The blue peak at 467 nm [25] comes from the defect related states such as oxygen vacancy or interstitial zinc. The weak and broad yellow emission at around 600 nm [28] is due to the deep levels caused by some defects. From the variation of the intensity of near band edge peak and the width of that peak with deposition time, it is seen from that the intensity of near band edge peak of the nanostructures deposited for 20 min is higher than the other nanostructures since there are more diamond-shaped structures.
Fig. 11
PL spectra of the nanostructures deposited at fixed substrate temperature of 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C for 10, 20, 40 and 60 min deposition time

Section2.Heading: Raman spectroscopy
Section2.Para:
The Raman spectra (Lab Ram HR-800, Jobin Yvon) were recorded using an Argon ion laser operating at a wavelength of 488 nm. ZnO has the wurtzite structure and belongs to
$$C_{6v}^4 $$
C
6 v
4
space group. Group theory predicts the existence of the following optic phonon modes [29],
$$\begin{aligned} \Gamma _\mathrm{opt} =A_1 +2B_1 +E_1 +2E_2 \end{aligned}$$
Γ opt
=
A 1
+ 2
B 1
+
E 1
+ 2
E 2
where
$$A_{1}$$
A 1
and
$$E_{1}$$
E 1
modes are polar and split into transverse optical (
$$A_{1}$$
A 1
TO and
$$E_{1}$$
E 1
TO) and longitudinal optical (
$$A_{1}$$
A 1
LO and
$$E_{1}$$
E 1
LO) components.
$$E_{2}$$
E 2
mode consists of two modes of low and high frequency phonons (
$$E_{2}$$
E 2
low and
$$E_{2}$$
E 2
high) which are associated with the vibration of the heavy Zn sub lattice and oxygen atoms, respectively.
$$B_{1 }$$
B 1
(low) and
$$B_{1 }$$
B 1
(high) modes are at 260 and 540 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
, respectively [29]. Two
$$B_{1}$$
B 1
modes are not Raman active [30]. High frequency
$$E_{2}$$
E 2
mode characterizes the wurtzite phase of ZnO [31]. The second order vibrations are at 208 and 330 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
. The broad peak at 330 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
is attributed to second-order Raman process. The broad peak at 663 cm
$$^{-1}$$
- 1
belongs to the multiphonon process [29].

Figure 12a shows the Raman spectrum of bulk ZnO. The Raman modes in bulk ZnO and ZnO nanostructures are shown in Table 1. In bulk ZnO,

$$^{\circ }$$

$$_{2 }$$

$$^{\circ }$$
∘

$$E_{2}$$

$$^{-1 }$$

$$E_{1}$$

The FWHM for the
$$E_{2}$$
E 2
(high) mode calculated from the Lorentzian fit of the Raman spectrum at various temperatures is plotted in Fig. 13. We observe that it is maximum at 450

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
The ZnO films were deposited on Si substrate and showed diamond-shaped structures prominently at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C. We also deposited ZnO films at different deposition time by fixing all other deposition parameters to explain the growth mechanism of diamond-shaped structures. The formation is discussed in the light of the different growth rates of the ZnO faces. XRD showed reduction in the (002) plane at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature and this change is attributed to high growth rate leading to the formation of diamond-shaped structures as observed in the FE-SEM images. The PL intensity is found to be enhanced for the films deposited at 150 and 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C substrate temperature due to the multiple reflections within the diamond-shaped ZnO structures. Raman spectra showed that the thin films have wurtzite structure due to the presence of
$$E_{2}$$
E 2
(high) mode and that the film crystallinity is poor at 450
$$^{\circ }$$
∘
C corroborating the XRD result. The analysis of FE-SEM images of the nanostructures deposited for fixed substrate temperature indicates the diamond-shaped structures are observed more for 20 min growth. The PL intensity is found to be enhanced for the films deposited for 20 min and optical properties are better for more diamond-shaped structures and nanowires/belts.

Acknowledgments.SimplePara: One of the authors (Poulami Ghosh) would like to thank the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), India for the financial support. Central Instruments Facility (CIF), IIT Guwahati is acknowledged for the FE-SEM images and Raman measurements.
